results.title: Police club for boys
results.creator_credit: Allen Stark, Bernard Devlin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1943 Montreal had 4000 juvenile delinquency cases; in 1948 it had 1800. The Police Juvenile Boys’ Club, started by Captain-Detective Ovila Pelletier, made all the difference. By providing youngsters who had few, if any, options in their leisure activities with the opportunity to learn, play and watch team sports, and to borrow the expensive sports equipment, he offered them a pleasing and acceptable alternative to delinquent behavior.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Stark, Bernard Devlin and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Poles apart
results.creator_credit: Judy Rymer, Paul Warren, Robert Dein, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Rymer Bayly Watson
results.brief_description: Gough Whitlam’s time in government symbolises the monumental shift in Australia from a country that was culturally bereft to one that blossomed, distancing itself from England for the first time to discover it’s cultural independence. Whitlam’s time in government was also marked by a number of initiatives of which some remain today like the establishing of the high court of Australia, reversal of conscription, changes to censorship laws, establishing the Australia Council, free tertiary education and a budget to purchase exemplary artworks for the country. Jackson Pollock’s ‘Blue Poles’ was the first and the most controversial of the purchased artworks. The symbolic purchase catapulted the sleepy Canberra onto the world stage declaring that Australia had arrived. This documentary with interviews, anecdotes and archival footage traces the history of the purchase of Blue Poles, but more significantly explores the profundity of it’s implications to Australian culture and society. Speakers include (the acerbic and witty) Gough Whitlam, (the youthful and articulate) James Mollison director of the NGA who purchased the work, Phillip Adams, Kirk Vernedoe (M.O.M.A.), Ben Heller (art dealer, N.Y.), Richard Feigan (art dealer, N.Y.), Lionel Bowen, Harry M. Millar, Frank Moorehouse, Lee Krasner, Frank Watters and Jack Mundey.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judy Rymer, Paul Warren, Robert Dein, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Rymer Bayly Watson

results.title: Pokemon: The Mystery of Mount Moon
results.creator_credit: Jim Malone, Michael Haigney, Norman J Grossfeld and Nintendo
results.brief_description: Pokemon trainer Ash Ketchum continues his quest to become the world’s greatest Pokemon master. He’s already caught two of the amazing creatures with the help of Pikachu. Together with Misty, they’ll travel across the land searching far and wide for all 150 Pokemon - he’s gotta catch ‘em all to be the very best. There are plenty of new creatures to learn about (and friends to meet) in this second set of Pokemon adventures. In Japanese, dubbed into English.

results.title: Pokemon: I choose you! Pikachu!
results.creator_credit: Masamitsu Hidaka, Keisuke Iwata, Takamoto Mori, Takayuki Yanagisawa, 4 Kids Productions and Shogakukan Production Co Ltd
results.brief_description: This volume contains the first three episodes of the Japanese (English Dubbed) cartoon. The first episode, entitled “I Choose You! Pikachu!” sees Ash, a ten year old boy get his first Pokemon (pocket monster). Having been late to the ceremony for choosing Pokemon, Ash is left with the last Pokemon, an electric rat Pokemon called Pikachu. After a bumpy start the two learn to work as a team to fight off a flock of Spearows: aggressive flying Pokemon. The second episode, entitled “Pokemon Emergency!” continues from the end of the battle with the Spearows in which Pikachu is badly hurt. Ash then has to rush his Pokemon to the special Pokemon hospital. While Ash waits for Pikachu to recover, the hospital is attacked by Team Rocket, an evil team of Pokemon thieves. Pikachu recovers just in time to work with Ash to scare off Team Rocket. Ash then continues on his quest to become a Pokemon master followed by Misty, a young girl who helped him save Pikachu. In third episode, entitled “Ash Catches a Pokemon”, Ash manages to catch his very first Pokemon, a big Pokemon called Caterpie. While Misty does not like Caterpie to begin with, things start to change after Caterpie saves the day when Team Rocket attempts another attack on Ash, Pikachu and Misty. Pokemon the series is based the Nintendo game of the same name.

results.title: Pokemon the first movie: Mewtwo strikes back
results.creator_credit: Kunihiko Yuyama, Michael Haigney, Choji Yoshikawa, Norman J Grossfeld, Takemoto Mori, Tomoyuki Igarashi, 4 Kids Productions and Pikachu Project '98
results.brief_description: Preceding the feature length Pokemon movie is a short animated Pokemon story called “Pikachu’s vacation” which really appears to be void of any substantial plot and is somewhat difficult to follow, particularly as there is not a lot of English narration accompanying the action. However Pokemon fans will no doubt enjoy the visuals and the familiar Japanese anime style of animation. “Pokemon the first movie: Mewtwo strikes back” questions several of todays moral and ethical dilemmas including cloning. The story begins with the birth of Mewtwo, a bio-engineered Pokemon created from the DNA of Mew, the rarest of all Pokemon. On discovering that he has been created for reseach purposes, Mewtwo becomes angry, breaking out of captivity. His mission is to eliminate all Pokemon and humans and let super clones rule the world. It is up to Ash Ketchum to save Earth, along with his human and Pokemon friends, including Pikachu. A battle like never before takes place, with original Pokemon fighting super clone Pokemon, Mewtwo fighting Mew, and Ash valiantly trying to put an end to the fighting. Themes such as friendship, loyalty, and non-violence are expounded and yet visually in terms of the fighting, the opposite takes place until near the very end of the story. Created by Satoshi Tajiri, written by Takeshi Shudo, with English adaptation directed by Michael Haigney. Dubbed in English. See also www.pokemonthemovie.com.

results.title: Poisons, pests and people
results.creator_credit: Larry Gosnell, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Produced in 1960, this still timely two-part film examines the effects of widespread chemical insecticide use, both on the insect population and on warm-blooded creatures, including humans. Part 1 looks at the ravages of insects and the centuries-old struggle to control them. Part 2 shows experiments being conducted to find ways of controlling specific insects, while leaving harmless ones unaffected.

results.title: Poison Ivy
results.creator_credit: Richard James Martin, Jack Long and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Sixty-six-year old Ivy Granstron jogs, skis, bowls and gardens and does carpentry work. Sometimes she walks into a wall. Due to insufficient care at birth, she has only 4 1/2 vision, but she doesn’t let blindness interfere with her life. She practices the art of ‘mind over eyes’.

results.title: Point break (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Kathryn Bigelow, Peter Abrams, Robert L Levy and Largo Entertainment
results.brief_description: Kathryn Bigelow’s (Strange Days, Blue Steel) fourth feature is a study of masculinity and surfer culture. Johnny Utah (Keanu Reeves) is a rookie FBI agent working undercover trying to crack an elite group of bank robbers who wear masks of ex-Presidents to hide their identities. As the criminals are thought to belong to an exclusive surfer cult, Utah learns to surf to infiltrate the group. Utah selects Tyler (Lori Petty), who is unaware of his true identity, to teach him the breaks that will make him a convincing surfer and keep his cover sound. Utah meets Bodhi (Patrick Swayze) a top surfer and adrenalin junkie, for whom surfing has a spiritual and mythical significance. “Point Break” is an action film that contains some impressive stunts including car chases, leaps from aeroplanes, exploding petrol stations and memorable scenes of breaking waves. Reeves is interestingly cast as the straight-laced policeman who has to learn the speech and mannerisms of a stoner dude. Filmed in Hawaii, California, Oregon and Bondi Beach, New South Wales.

results.title: Poetry for an Englishman
results.brief_description: A young girl, living with her family in a lighthouse, is fascinated by her brother’s aloofness and observes his relationship with an English sailor from a distance. Based on a short story, “My brother writes poetry for an Englishman” by Marris Murray. Cast includes Georgina Bradley (Janie), Nathan Dutton (brother), Anna Volska (mother) and John Sheerin (father).
